raw_text:
Redknapp poised for Saints
 
 Southampton are set to unveil Harry Redknapp as their new manager at a news conference at 1500 GMT on Wednesday.
 
 The former Portsmouth boss replaces Steve Wigley, who has been relieved of first-team duties after just one win in 14 league games in charge. Redknapp, 57, quit his Fratton Park position on 24 November and vowed: "I will not go down the road - no chance." Pompey coach Kevin Bond is poised to join Redknapp, who will be Saints' third boss of the season. Redknapp's first game in charge will be at home to Middlesbrough on Saturday. Portsmouth chairman Milan Mandaric said he was "disappointed" by the news and claimed Redknapp had been in talks with Southampton for "some time".
 
 "It would appear that negotiations over this have been going on for some time," Mandaric said on Portsmouth's official website. "I am surprised and a little shocked that the chairman of Southampton has not picked up the phone and kept me informed." According to Mandaric, Redknapp vowed he would not join their South coast rivals when he left Portsmouth. "I said to Harry 'I hope you don't go to Southampton', and he told me 'absolutely not'," he said. "I'm wouldn't say I'm bitter, disgusted or angry, just disappointed, but it's Harry's life and it's his decision." Redknapp became a cult hero after leading Portsmouth into the Premiership for the first time, and then masterminding their survival in their debut season. But he left the club claiming he needed a break from football, though many believed he was upset with Mandaric's decision to bring in Velimir Zajec as executive director.
 
 Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe was desperate to give former academy director Wigley, who replaced Paul Sturrock just two games into the season, every chance to succeed at St Mary's. But results under Wigley have been poor and Southampton are deep in trouble near the foot of the table. When Redknapp's appointment is confirmed, he will be Saints' ninth manager in eight years.

Redknapp's first game in charge is against Middlesbrough on Saturday. Pompey chairman Milan Mandaric was disappointed with the news and accused Redknapp of not informing him about his new position, claiming he had previous talks with Southampton but has not yet received confirmation.

Redknapp, who quit Portsmouth on 24 November, is Southampton's third manager this season and will face Middlesbrough at home on Saturday. Portsmouth chairman Milan Mandaric was disappointed by the appointment and claims Redknapp had been in talks for some time with Southampton, despite Redknapp stating he would not join his South Coast rivals when he left Portsmouth. Redknapp previously led Portsmouth to their first Premier League and then helped them survive in their debut season. Southampton have experienced nine managers in eight years, with Lowe desperate for a change following Wigley's poor results.

Redknapp's first game in charge will be at home on Saturday when he takes over from Steve Wigley who has been relieved of his first-team duties after just one win in 14 league games.

Redknapp is set to join Saints' third boss, Kevin Bond, who will be Saints' new head coach. Redknapp's first game in charge will be at home on Saturday when he takes over from Bond who will be overseeing the Saints' second season under him. Redknapp is set to take over as Saints manager at a news conference in 1500 GMT on Wednesday, replacing Steve Wigley after his first win. Redknapp promised not to go down the road and will face Middlesbrough for his first game against his new team. Kevin Bond joins him, and Redknapp will lead Saints' season starting in Portsmouth. Mandaric was disappointed with Southampton's chairman and seemed unaware of the news about Redknapp. Redknapp became a fan favorite after leading Portsmouth to the Premiership and managed their debut season well but left after needing a break.
tinyllama:1.1b: In response to rumors circulating that Harry Redknapp was poised to become Saint Louis' new manager, a news conference has been announced at 1500 GMT on Wednesday for the unveiling of Redknapp as Saint Louis's third manager. The former Portsmouth boss is set to succeed Steve Wigley, who resigned after just one win in 14 league games. Redknapp voiced his displeasure over rumors about him joining Saint Louis' rivals, but there were no official announcements until the news conference. Redknapp was said to have been in talks with Southampton for some time and would not join their struggling South coast rivals if he left Portsmouth. However, it remains unclear whether Redknapp will actually become Saint Louis's manager or remain at his current position as Portsmouth coach, given the club's financial struggles and poor results. The news conference is expected to be attended by Saint Louis chairman Milan Mandarić, who was reportedly disappointed but not angry about Redknapp's decision.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Southampton announced the hiring of Harry Redknapp as their new manager on Wednesday evening. The former Portsmouth boss replaces Steve Wigley, who had been in charge for just one win in 14 league games. Redknapp left Fratton Park due to concerns about the team's performance and undertook a short period of rest before joining up with the Saints as a potential candidate.

Redknapp's tenure at Southampton may not be successful if his decision to join the club does not coincide with a significant improvement in their performance on the pitch. The team is currently placed 16th in the Premier League, and Redknapp will have to work with an underwhelming group of players to turn things around for them.

Wigley has been relieved of first-team duties following a disappointing start to the season, but Redknapp's appointment is seen as another opportunity for the club to rebuild and compete on a higher level. Pompey fans have expressed their dissatisfaction with Wigley's handling of the team, and some believe that Redknapp could bring stability and success to the club.

The new manager will take charge of Southampton's match against Middlesbrough on Saturday, and his first game in charge will likely be at home against Premier League side, Portsmouth, on November 24th. The team is currently seventh in the league table with just eight points from ten matches.

The appointment of Redknapp comes as a surprise to Pompey fans, who were expecting to see either Mandaric or Velimir Zajec take over at St Mary's after the club lost their first game under Wigley's leadership. The appointment could also signal an increase in confidence for Southampton, given Redknapp's successful tenure at Pompey and his ability to manage a team with a roster of talented players.

The chairman of Southampton claimed he did not know about Redknapp's appointment and that negotiations with Portsmouth had been going on for some time. He also mentioned that Redknapp had promised him he would not go to their rivals, which surprised him as he believed it was Harry's decision.
